newsitem.title: USA: US House panel votes to ban federal funds for cloning.
newsitem.headline: US House panel votes to ban federal funds for cloning.

text.p: The House of Representatives Science Committee approved on Tuesday legislation banning federal funding for research on human cloning, the first congressional panel to act on the controversial issue.
The bill, which passed on a voice vote, prohibits the use of federal money for experimentation with cell transfer technology to produce an embryo which is a human clone.
Human somatic cell nuclear transfer technology involves the transfer of the nucleus of a human cell which will not become a sperm or egg to an egg from which the nucleus has been removed.

"I think it is extremely important for us to make a statement to society that human cloning is not acceptable in the United States of America and that we are going to prohibit federal funding for research on human cloning," said Representative Vernon Ehlers, a Michigan Republican and the chief sponsor of the bill.
The bill does allow for continuation of federal research on plant and animal cloning, as well as other forms of genetic science, such as breast cancer research.
Once the legislation is approved by the House Commerce Committee, it will go to the House for a floor vote.

The committee also approved on a voice vote a bill to encourage the use of private-sector technology to protect computers at civilian government agencies, and a measure which authorises funding for earthquake research and hazards mitigation.
